Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Landmark-Guided and Ultrasound-Guided Intra-Articular Analgesic Injections for Shoulder Dislocation Reduction

Background: Effective pain control during shoulder dislocation reduction is crucial. This study compares landmark-guided and ultrasound-guided intra-articular analgesic injections.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary referral care center between August 2021 and March 2023. Twenty-eight patients with anterior shoulder dislocation were randomly assigned to either the landmark-guided or ultrasound-guided intra-articular lidocaine injection group. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes. The primary outcome was pain reduction, measured using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) before and after injection, and before injection and after reduction. Secondary outcomes included length of stay in the emergency department and complications. Patients were followed for 2 weeks. Blinding was not applied to patients or clinicians.

Results: Fourteen patients were randomised to each group. There were no significant differences in pain reduction between preinjection and postinjection (landmark-guided: ΔVAS 2.8 ± 1.1, ultrasound-guided: ΔVAS 2.9 ± 1.0; p = 0.72) or between preinjection and postreduction (landmark-guided: ΔVAS 6.6 ± 2.1, ultrasound-guided: ΔVAS 5.8 ± 1.8; p = 0.30). Length of stay was similar (landmark-guided: 162 ± 38 minutes, ultrasound-guided: 184 ± 73 minutes; p = 0.33). No complications were reported.

Interpretation: Both techniques were equally effective in pain management and had similar lengths of stay and complication rates. These findings assist orthopaedic surgeons in choosing the appropriate technique based on resources and expertise.
